description: The Exodus-Revelation parallels demonstrate that John consciously presents end-time events as a 'new exodus' - God's ultimate act of liberating his people from cosmic oppression. The Egyptian plagues directly inform the trumpet and bowl judgments: water turned to blood, darkness, hail, locusts, and death of firstborn find eschatological counterparts. The Song of Moses and the Lamb (Revelation 15:3) explicitly connects the two events. The Passover Lamb becomes the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world. The exodus typology shows that God who delivered Israel from Pharaoh will deliver the church from the dragon and beast.
longDescription:
The Book of Revelation presents eschatological judgment as a recapitulation and intensification of the Exodus plagues. John's first-century audience, steeped in Scripture, would immediately recognize these connections:

Plague Correspondences:

1. Water to Blood:
   - Exodus 7:14-25: The Nile turned to blood, fish died
   - Revelation 8:8-9 (Second Trumpet): One-third of sea becomes blood
   - Revelation 16:3-6 (Second/Third Bowls): Sea and rivers become blood; 'they deserve it'

2. Frogs:
   - Exodus 8:1-15: Frogs cover Egypt
   - Revelation 16:13: Three evil spirits 'that looked like frogs' from dragon, beast, and false prophet

3. Darkness:
   - Exodus 10:21-29: Three days of darkness over Egypt
   - Revelation 8:12 (Fourth Trumpet): One-third of sun, moon, stars darkened
   - Revelation 16:10 (Fifth Bowl): Darkness on beast's kingdom

4. Hail:
   - Exodus 9:13-35: Hail and fire destroy crops and livestock
   - Revelation 8:7 (First Trumpet): Hail and fire mixed with blood
   - Revelation 16:21 (Seventh Bowl): Hundred-pound hailstones

5. Locusts:
   - Exodus 10:1-20: Locusts devour vegetation
   - Revelation 9:1-11 (Fifth Trumpet): Demonic locusts from the Abyss

6. Death of Firstborn:
   - Exodus 12:29-30: Egypt's firstborn die; Israel's protected by lamb's blood
   - Revelation 14:9-11: Death for those with beast's mark; protection for sealed 144,000

The Song of Moses and the Lamb (Revelation 15:3-4):
Before the bowl judgments, the victorious saints sing 'the song of Moses the servant of God AND the song of the Lamb.' This explicit connection joins Exodus 15 (Israel's victory song at the Red Sea) with eschatological deliverance. The new exodus completes and exceeds the old.

Passover/Lamb Typology:
The Passover lamb whose blood protected Israel from the death angel becomes 'the Lamb that was slain from the creation of the world' (13:8). The Lamb's blood marks and protects the 144,000. The marriage supper of the Lamb (19:9) echoes Passover's communal meal.
historicalContext:
The Exodus narrative formed Israel's foundational identity as God's redeemed people. Second Isaiah (Isaiah 40-55) already presented the return from Babylon as a 'new exodus.' By the first century, exodus typology was well-established in Jewish eschatological expectation.

Early Christians understood their redemption through Christ as exodus fulfillment. Paul wrote, 'Christ, our Passover lamb, has been sacrificed' (1 Corinthians 5:7). The Gospel of John presents Jesus' death at Passover time. Revelation extends this typology to the cosmic level.

John's plague sequence both follows and expands the Exodus pattern. The Egyptian plagues were limited and sequential; Revelation's plagues are cosmic in scope, affecting thirds (trumpets) and then totalities (bowls) of creation. The escalation shows that end-time judgment exceeds all previous divine interventions.

The textual traditions of both Exodus and Revelation are well-preserved. John's Greek reflects his own engagement with the Hebrew text, creating distinctive echoes recognizable to biblically literate readers.
theologicalSignificance:
The Exodus-Revelation connection establishes crucial theological truths:

1. Salvation History Continuity: God who acted in Exodus continues to act in the same ways at history's climax. Divine faithfulness extends across millennia.

2. Liberation Theology: Exodus established God as liberator of the oppressed. Revelation assures persecuted Christians that their oppressor (Rome/Babylon) will face Egypt's fate.

3. Lamb Christology: The Passover lamb typology interprets Christ's death as redemptive liberation. The slain Lamb who conquers is Israel's hope fulfilled.

4. Judgment as Justice: As the Egyptian plagues vindicated Israel against oppressors, Revelation's plagues vindicate the martyrs. 'They have shed the blood of your holy people and prophets, and you have given them blood to drink as they deserve' (16:6).

5. Divine Warrior: God who fought against Egypt fights against the dragon. The Song of Moses ('The LORD is a warrior,' Exodus 15:3) continues in the Lamb's victory.

6. Community Identity: As Israel was constituted by Exodus experience, the church is constituted by the Lamb's redemption - a new people formed by a new exodus.

keyPassages.text: They held harps given them by God and sang the song of God's servant Moses and of the Lamb: 'Great and marvelous are your deeds, Lord God Almighty. Just and true are your ways, King of the nations. Who will not fear you, Lord, and bring glory to your name? For you alone are holy. All nations will come and worship before you, for your righteous acts have been revealed.'
keyPassages.significance: The explicit connection of Moses and Lamb

keyPassages.text: The third angel poured out his bowl on the rivers and springs of water, and they became blood. Then I heard the angel in charge of the waters say: 'You are just in these judgments, O Holy One, you who are and who were; for they have shed the blood of your holy people and prophets, and you have given them blood to drink as they deserve.'
keyPassages.significance: Blood plague reinterpreted as just retribution

keyPassages.text: Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the LORD: 'I will sing to the LORD, for he is highly exalted. Both horse and driver he has hurled into the sea. The LORD is my strength and my defense; he has become my salvation.'
keyPassages.significance: The original Song of Moses celebrating deliverance

comparativeNotes.secondTempleJudaism: The Wisdom of Solomon (11-19) extensively develops exodus plague typology. Passover Haggadot elaborate the plague narratives. Philo's Life of Moses interprets the exodus allegorically. John works within this established tradition of exodus reinterpretation.
comparativeNotes.paulineTheology: Paul's exodus typology (1 Corinthians 5:7; 10:1-11) provides New Testament precedent. Christ as Passover lamb, baptism as Red Sea crossing, and the wilderness journey as church experience prepare for Revelation's cosmic development.
comparativeNotes.liberationTheology: Modern liberation theology draws heavily on exodus as paradigm for God's identification with the oppressed. Revelation extends this to cosmic scale - God liberates from ultimate oppressors (dragon, beast, Babylon) as from Egypt.

author: Moses (Traditional), John (Apostle)
